@MASTERBTCLTC The first halving was about 40 days early.\nThe second halving was about 4.5 months early.\nThe third halving is about 2 months early.

Bitcoin mining began Jan 8, 2009.
Halving eras are 210,000 blocks (~4 years)
So why is the 3rd halving not happening in Jan 2021?
It's because the hashrate continues relentlessly accelerating; difficulty adjustments help slow down blocks, but they can only do so much.

Q: How is the price of bitcoin set?\nA: Same as any freely traded asset. People place bids to buy at various prices while others set asks to sell at various prices. At the point of intersection, bids match with asks and a trade occurs. The most recent trade is the current price.

@notsofast @dahifi @stephendpalley In technical terms a "covenant" generally refers to a setup by which you can "claw back" a transaction that is spent from your vault without your approval.

Bitcoin may be the first asset that can be stored in such a way that it has no single physical footprint. As such, it's the easiest asset to defend against nation state attacks. All you need to do is distribute keys to a multisig setup across jurisdictions that don't cooperate.

@notsofast @dahifi @stephendpalley Yeah, "covenants" or "vaults" with various logical branches are also interesting. The main issue at the moment is the additional complexity they create. This adds additional burden around how to manage certain disaster recovery scenarios.
@notsofast @dahifi @stephendpalley It's certainly possible to design key storage setups that protect against this risk. https://t.co/lSoMhiq5T8
@deepfayk A "soft target" is a person or thing that is relatively unprotected or vulnerable to attack. A well defended person / thing is referred to as "hard target."

@JohnBostick @CasaHODL Yes, the knowledge of the specific balance doesn't affect the actual security of your keys. If someone has targeted you for your bitcoin then they have already decided that you're worth risking their life / freedom to attack. We do have a "hide balances" setting for casual use.

@JohnBostick @CasaHODL That's one possible scenario, though I don't recommend biometrics for a phone lock - I use a PIN.\n\nWhen it comes to security level, I recommend taking your current value and multiplying by 10 when thinking through if your protections are sufficient to disincentivize an attacker.

@AndrewRogovets Well, in Bitcoin there is no such thing as addresses - that's just a human abstraction for usability. They'd have to have spend the exact UTXO they claimed to have spent to you in order to make your transaction invalid. Hard to do accidentally.
@AndrewRogovets Ah there you go, some nodes are rejecting your transaction because they consider it to be a double spend. Would require more in depth analysis to figure out why.

@AndrewRogovets It really depends on what wallet software you are using, in many cases it may be difficult to do. Also keep in mind that there's currently 20 blocks worth of transactions in the mempool; if yours is paying a low fee then it will take many hours for it to get confirmed.

@AndrewRogovets There are no guarantees about mempools on different nodes being in sync; every node can run its own policies around relaying transactions. Some block explorers have "push" functions where you can give them your fully signed txn hex, like https://t.co/BW9e8WDCrf
@AndrewRogovets It could be RBF related or that transaction might not be propagating well due to any number of possible transaction attributes.

@killerstorm I agree that miners use mathematical functions as a part of their work, but it's not a "math problem" in the sense that you execute a formula and get a solution. The real problem (the work) is a result of the solution being random and the formula being a guess.

Less than 6 months until we enter the 4th era of bitcoin inflation, at which point BTC will fall below the 2% inflation rate targeted by the Federal Reserve.\nhttps://t.co/qnZjhALJBh

Bitcoin miners don't "solve complicated math problems."
They make 100,000,000,000,000,000,000 guesses per second @ permutations of an 80 byte block header until they find one with a hash that has enough leading zeroes.
Not complicated.
Not a math problem.
Just a lot of hard work.

@agent_scruples @saifedean Ultimately I believe the safest thing may be to just have informational messages notifying a human operator that something is wonky and manual intervention may be desired. If you automate any decisive actions, you risk consensus failures.

@agent_scruples @saifedean Sounds like the same logic Bitcoin ABC implemented, but theirs is 10 blocks. Primary opposition to such logic is that it breaks the guarantee that all nodes running the same software will converge on the same chain.
@saifedean Is it possible to write such software? Sure, but the more automated you make it, the more susceptible it is to being exploited. See: announcement system that was removed from Bitcoin Core.
@nic__carter Methinks cryptotwitter underestimates the apathy of node operators.

@saifedean My issue is that I don't know what "preparing a UASF" means in this context. How do you prepare for an unknown event? Normally you'd need every node operator to manually run an "invalidateblock" command on their node to reject the block creating a reorg - this is onerous.

@saifedean To be more specific: Bitcoin rarely has reorgs more than 1 block deep these days. I'd expect it to have deeper (but still shallow) reorgs from time to time. I think a deep reorg > 100 could create potential for a UASF; coordination would still be hard.

@saifedean This statement is controversial. Some folks would prefer that reorgs happen more frequently in order to make it more clear to the userbase exactly how the PoW model works. It's not binary, but rather confidence driven by provably required energy expenditure.

@saifedean The incentives get complicated quite quickly and thus coordination is more likely to break down. If Alice steals from Bob and then Bob gets Charlie to help him revert the theft, what's my incentive to do anything about it?

@saifedean Because instead of a handful of mining pools we're talking thousands of node operators, many of whom don't pay attention to the day to day drama. For either case (chain reorg or UASF) new software would need to be written to make such coordination possible.

@thibm_ @AlenaSatoshi @QuadrigaCoinEx @CasaHODL There is no "recovery material" - that why we call it a seedless wallet. If a device is lost / compromised, the other devices are used to replace the lost device/keyset.

@BitcoinTina @thibm_ @AlenaSatoshi @QuadrigaCoinEx @CasaHODL We advise users about firmware updates; not all firmware updates wipe the seed from a device. If they do, then the user must perform a key rotation in their wallet after updating the device and generating a new seed.

@thibm_ @AlenaSatoshi @QuadrigaCoinEx @CasaHODL Users have custody of all but 1 key for multisig, on their own hardware devices. Casa can't steal funds, but if we ceased to exist you'd be able to use open source software to recover your multisig wallet.
